'''Morality''', in the strictest sense of the word, deals with that which is regarded as right or wrong. The term is often used to refer to a system of principles and judgments shared by [[cultural]], [[religion|religious]], [[secular]] (e.g. [[secular humanism|Humanist]]) and [[philosophical]] communities who share concepts and beliefs, by which people determine whether given actions are [[Goodness_and_value_theory|right]] or [[evil|wrong]].
+
'''Morality''', in the strictest sense of the word, deals with that which is regarded as right or wrong. The term is often used to refer to a system of principles and judgments shared by [[cultural]], [[religion|religious]], [[secular]] (e.g. [[secular humanism|Humanist]]) and [[philosophical]] communities who share concepts and beliefs, by which people determine whether given actions are [[Goodness and value theory|right]] or [[evil|wrong]].
     
These concepts and beliefs about right and wrong are often generalized and codified by a culture or group, and thus serve to regulate the behavior of its members. Conformity to such codification may also be called ''morality'', and the group may depend on widespread conformity to such codes for its continued existence. Individuals who choose to conform in this way are popularly held to possess "Moral Fibre", whereas those who lack "Moral Fibre" may be labelled as socially [[degenerate]]. A "moral" may refer to a particular principle, usually as an informal and general summary with respect to a moral principle, as it is applied in a given human situation.
 
These concepts and beliefs about right and wrong are often generalized and codified by a culture or group, and thus serve to regulate the behavior of its members. Conformity to such codification may also be called ''morality'', and the group may depend on widespread conformity to such codes for its continued existence. Individuals who choose to conform in this way are popularly held to possess "Moral Fibre", whereas those who lack "Moral Fibre" may be labelled as socially [[degenerate]]. A "moral" may refer to a particular principle, usually as an informal and general summary with respect to a moral principle, as it is applied in a given human situation.
Line 49: Line 49:  
A common version of a moral code is a [[legal code]] which states the penalties or corrective actions associated with any particular act (note that many of the legal codes are built on a foundaton of religion).
 
A common version of a moral code is a [[legal code]] which states the penalties or corrective actions associated with any particular act (note that many of the legal codes are built on a foundaton of religion).
    −
A [[value system]], which is the prioritization of the [[value#Personal_and_cultural_values|values]] held by an individual or group, can also be used to form the basis of a moral code.
+
A [[value system]], which is the prioritization of the [[Value (personal and cultural)|values]] held by an individual or group, can also be used to form the basis of a moral code.
     
In some cultures, the relationship between moral and legal codes are often absolute - they're one and the same. Moral codes help drive [[personal conduct]].
 
In some cultures, the relationship between moral and legal codes are often absolute - they're one and the same. Moral codes help drive [[personal conduct]].
